summary: This is an FBI Special Agent's affidavit in support of a search warrant application for electronic devices and media seized from or associated with Jeffrey Epstein. It details the seizure of items from Epstein upon his arrest, the discovery of thousands of nude/suggestive images of young females at his New York residence, and the subsequent removal and recovery of additional evidence. The affidavit establishes probable cause for sex trafficking of minors and conspiracy.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The financier accused of sex trafficking of minors and conspiracy. The affidavit details his arrest, the seizure of his electronic devices, and the evidence found at his New York residence.

persons.name: Barbara Moses
persons.context: Signed the initial indictment arrest warrant and multiple search warrants for Epstein's New York residence and seized discs.

persons.name: Kevin Nathaniel Fox
persons.context: Signed the search warrant application and affidavit on July 15, 2019.

persons.name: Henry B. Pitman
persons.context: Signed the fourth search warrant for the New York residence on July 11, 2019.

persons.name: Geoffrey S. Berman
persons.context: Listed as the United States Attorney on the sealed indictment against Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Alison Moe
persons.context: Named as the AUSA contact on the arrest warrant for Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Victim-1
persons.context: A victim identified in the indictment who was sexually abused by Epstein between 2002-2005 while under 18. Provided information to the FBI.

persons.name: Individual-1
persons.context: A young girl identified from photographs on seized discs, who was 17 when partially nude photos of her were taken at a location she recalled.

persons.name: Employee
persons.context: An employee who, after the initial search, was instructed by a third party to remove contents from a safe and deliver them in suitcases.

persons.name: Third Party
persons.context: An unnamed individual who instructed the Employee to remove items from the safe, received the suitcases, and later turned them over to law enforcement.

persons.name: Employee-1
persons.context: Identified in the indictment as a New York-based employee who communicated with victims to schedule sexual encounters for Epstein.

persons.name: Employee-2
persons.context: Identified in the indictment as an assistant responsible for scheduling sexual encounters with minor victims at the Palm Beach residence.

persons.name: Employee-3
persons.context: Identified in the indictment as an assistant responsible for scheduling sexual encounters with minor victims at the Palm Beach residence.

persons.name: Minor Victim-1
persons.context: A minor victim recruited in 2002, repeatedly abused by Epstein in New York, paid for encounters, and encouraged to recruit other girls. Told Epstein her age.

persons.name: Minor Victim-2
persons.context: A minor victim recruited in 2004, repeatedly abused by Epstein in Palm Beach, paid for encounters, and encouraged to recruit other girls.

persons.name: Minor Victim-3
persons.context: A minor victim recruited in 2005, repeatedly abused by Epstein in Palm Beach, paid for encounters, and encouraged to recruit other girls. Told Epstein her age.

connections.description: Epstein directed Employee-1, a New York-based employee, to communicate with victims to schedule sexual encounters at the New York residence.
Epstein arranged for Employee-2 to contact victims to schedule encounters at the Palm Beach residence prior to his travel.
Employee-3 placed phone calls to schedule appointments for victims to engage in sex acts with Epstein at the Palm Beach residence.
Epstein sexually abused Minor Victim-1 repeatedly at the New York Residence from 2002, paid her, and encouraged her to recruit other girls.
The Employee worked at Epstein's New York residence and followed instructions from a Third Party to remove evidence from the safe.
The Third Party instructed the Employee to remove evidence from Epstein's safe and received the suitcases containing that evidence.
The affidavit references payments to individuals named as possible co-conspirators in a prior non-prosecution agreement, suggesting ongoing communication and influence.

events.title: Indictment and Arrest Warrant Issued
events.description: A grand jury returned an indictment charging Jeffrey Epstein with sex trafficking of minors and conspiracy. Magistrate Judge Barbara Moses signed an arrest warrant.

events.title: Arrest and Initial Seizure at Teterboro
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein arrived at Teterboro Airport from France. CBP agents searched him, found an iPhone and iPad (Subject Items 1 & 2), and FBI agents placed him under arrest.

events.title: Search of New York Residence
events.description: Law enforcement executed search warrants at 9 East 71st Street. They discovered a safe containing binders of CDs with labels referencing young girls, nudes, and Epstein's properties, as well as a shoebox with similar discs and Polaroids.

events.title: Recovery of Removed Evidence
events.description: Upon executing a fourth warrant, agents found the safe empty. An Employee stated they had been instructed by a Third Party to remove the contents. The Third Party later turned over two suitcases containing the missing binders and hard drives.

events.title: Miami Herald Series Publication
events.description: The Miami Herald began publishing a series of articles about Epstein's sex trafficking and a prior non-prosecution agreement.

events.title: $100,000 Payment to Co-conspirator
events.description: Two days after the Miami Herald series began, Epstein wired $100,000 from a trust account to an individual named as a possible co-conspirator in the NPA.

events.title: $250,000 Payment to Co-conspirator
events.description: Three days after the first payment, Epstein wired $250,000 to another individual named as a possible co-conspirator and identified as an employee in the indictment.

events.title: Period of Alleged Abuse
events.description: The indictment alleges Epstein sexually abused multiple minor girls at his New York and Palm Beach residences, paying them cash and using victim-recruiters to find more girls.

locations: 9 East 71st Street, New York, New York (New York Residence)
Teterboro Airport, Bergen County, New Jersey
Zorro Ranch (Epstein's property in New Mexico)
Little Saint James (Epstein's property in U.S. Virgin Islands)
keyFacts: The affidavit supports a search warrant for six specific items: an iPhone, an iPad, two binders with CDs, two hard drives, a box of CDs, and two more binders with CDs, all seized from or associated with Jeffrey Epstein.

Searches of Epstein's New York residence revealed thousands of nude or partially nude photographs of girls and young women, many appearing to be under 18, stored on CDs with labels like 'Young [Name]', 'Nudes 00-24', 'Girl Pies Nude', and references to 'Zorro' and 'LSJ' (his properties).

After an initial search on July 7, 2019, an employee removed the contents of a safe containing discs and hard drives and delivered them to a third party, who later surrendered the items to the FBI on July 11.

Following the publication of the Miami Herald series in November 2018, Epstein made substantial wire payments ($100,000 and $250,000) to individuals named as possible co-conspirators in a prior non-prosecution agreement.

The indictment incorporated into the affidavit details a scheme where Epstein abused minor girls, paid them in cash, and used victim-recruiters to bring him additional underage girls, knowing their ages.
